footnotes:
Having introduced both \glsxtrlongabb:ml in \Crefsub:general_notions_of_ml
and \glsxtrlongabb:ec in \Crefsub:edge_computing,
we dedicate this section to discussing their combination.
We are particularly interested in \glsabb:dl on the edge,
since \glsplabb:dnn are both very popular, and easy to parallelize.
In all generality, the process of training a \glsabb:ml models on the edge
is depicted in \Creffig:edge_ml_process.
End devices collect data from their environment,
optionally preprocessing or temporally storing it,
before sending it to an edge node.

The edge node aggregates, processes, and stores the data,
before training its local model on it,
possibly invoking the server for orchestration or heavy computations.
The server manages the training process
and performs the computations delegated to it by the edge nodes.
During each step of this process,
edge nodes can respond to client inference requests
using their current local model.

The number of proposed techniques to train \glsabb:ml models on the edge is beyond what can be covered in a single section. Therefore, we focus on two of the most popular techniques: distributed learning and federated learning, directing the reader’s attention to Khouas et al. (2024) for a review of other techniques. Khouas et al. (2024) for a review of other techniques.

abb:dq is the central focus of this survey. It is an extremely broad topic, not only in \glsabb:ml but also in data science, data engineering, database management, information systems, and multiple other adjacent disciplines, as evidenced by the numerous works on the subject Xu et al. (2023); Gupta et al. (2021); Olson (2003); Mahanti (2019); Renggli et al. (2021); Camacho et al. (2023); Gudivada et al. (2017) and the equally numerous approaches these works take to study it. In this section, we explore Xu et al. (2023); Gupta et al. (2021); Olson (2003); Mahanti (2019); Renggli et al. (2021); Camacho et al. (2023); Gudivada et al. (2017) and the equally numerous approaches these works take to study it. In this section, we explore \glsabb:dq for \glsabb:ml data as it is covered in the existing literature, with particular focus on the questions of: (i) what is data quality? (i.e., how it is defined), (ii) what characterizes a good dataset? (data quality dimensions), and (iii) how is data quality ensured? (existing solutions). As such, this section is divided into three parts, each corresponding to one of the above questions (in order).

The so-called \glsabb:iid assumption is the bedrock for much of the classical theory (and practice) of \glsabb:ml  Vapnik (2010); Liu et al. (2023). While convenient for theoretical analysis, the Vapnik (2010); Liu et al. (2023). While convenient for theoretical analysis, the \glsabb:iid assumption is not a realistic model of real-world data Liu et al. (2023), an observation that is even more salient in Liu et al. (2023), an observation that is even more salient in \glsabb:fl on the edge Xia et al. (2021); Wang et al. (2021); Li et al. (2020). In general, the Xia et al. (2021); Wang et al. (2021); Li et al. (2020). In general, the \glsabb:iid assumption can fail in two ways, the data can be either (i) dependent, or (ii) it can fail to be equidistributed according to the true distribution Pr ( X , Y ) subscript Pr 𝑋 𝑌 \Pr_{(X,Y)} roman_Pr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_Y ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Pr ( X , Y ) subscript Pr 𝑋 𝑌 \Pr_{(X,Y)} roman_Pr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_Y ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Pr ( X , Y ) Pr Pr ( X , Y ) ( (X X, ,Y Y) ) subscript Pr 𝑋 𝑌 subscript Pr 𝑋 𝑌 subscript subscriptPr Pr 𝑋 𝑌 𝑋 𝑋𝑌 𝑌\Pr_{(X,Y)} \Pr_{(X,Y)}roman_Pr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_Y ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Pr start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X , italic_Y ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this section, we discuss the first of these two issues, leaving the second for \Crefsec:equidistribution,sec:noise.

The majority of works in the literature on learning from dependent data Zou et al. (2009); Guo and Shi (2011); Zimin (2018); Roy et al. (2021) relies on the theory of stochastic processes. The typical approach is to replace the independence part of the Zou et al. (2009); Guo and Shi (2011); Zimin (2018); Roy et al. (2021) relies on the theory of stochastic processes. The typical approach is to replace the independence part of the \glsabb:iid assumption with a weaker condition like mixing Guo and Shi (2011). This is sometimes accompanied by a strengthening of the Guo and Shi (2011). This is sometimes accompanied by a strengthening of the identically distributed part to a stationarity condition Roy et al. (2021); Dundar et al. (????). The alternate set of assumptions is then used to derive generalization bounds analogous to those available in the Roy et al. (2021); Dundar et al. (????). The alternate set of assumptions is then used to derive generalization bounds analogous to those available in the \glsabb:iid case.

Notable deviations from this approach include the work of Lauer (2023) and Lauer (2023) and Dundar et al. (????). The former presents derivations of classical generalization bounds such as those based on the Dundar et al. (????). The former presents derivations of classical generalization bounds such as those based on the \glsabb:vc dimension Vapnik (1998), or the Rademacher complexity of the hypothesis class, without assuming independence, nor replacing it with another condition. The latter on the other hand, takes a more practical approach, leveraging (actual or assumed) information about the structure of the dependence to train linear classifiers on dependent data. Vapnik (1998), or the Rademacher complexity of the hypothesis class, without assuming independence, nor replacing it with another condition. The latter on the other hand, takes a more practical approach, leveraging (actual or assumed) information about the structure of the dependence to train linear classifiers on dependent data.

The problem of data dependence in \glsabb:fl on edge devices remains largely unexplored. In our review of the literature, we could not find any edge or \glsabb:fl-specific works that address the issue of dependent data. This is not indicative of a general lack of interest in the effect of \glsabb:iid violations on \glsabb:fl, which is one of the most active areas of research in the field, even more so in the case of edge \glsabb:fl Xia et al. (2021). Most of these works, however, disregard the question of dependence, in favor of focusing on distribution mismatch  Xia et al. (2021). Most of these works, however, disregard the question of dependence, in favor of focusing on distribution mismatch Wang et al. (2021); Li et al. (2020); Lee (2023). The absence of works on dependent data in Wang et al. (2021); Li et al. (2020); Lee (2023). The absence of works on dependent data in \glsabb:fl, coupled with the localized nature of the edge environment, which can lead to strong dependence between the data points of one device or a set of similar devices, and the difficulty of detecting such dependence due to privacy constraints, suggests that this is a promising direction for future research.

The second (and arguably the most important) component
of the \glsabb:iid assumption is for all random pairs in the sample
to be drawn from the true distribution.
If this is not the case, the empirical risk is not guaranteed to converge to the true risk,
negating guarantees on the consistency of \glsabb:erm.

When multiple edge devices participate in \glsabb:fl, their local datasets are often heterogeneous Abreha et al. (2022). For example, two wearable devices owned by people of different ages and physical activity levels are extremely unlikely to have similarly distributed datasets. Therefore, aggregating models trained on these datasets will not necessarily yield an unbiased estimate of the model trained on their union  Abreha et al. (2022). For example, two wearable devices owned by people of different ages and physical activity levels are extremely unlikely to have similarly distributed datasets. Therefore, aggregating models trained on these datasets will not necessarily yield an unbiased estimate of the model trained on their union Zhao et al. (2018). Zhao et al. (2018).

Addressing this issue is one of the most active areas of research in \glsabb:fl. The corpus of literature on the topic is expansive, diverse, and rapidly growing, covering a wide range of topics from theoretical guarantees Li et al. (2020); Lee (2023) to practical solutions  Li et al. (2020); Lee (2023) to practical solutions Wang et al. (2021); Zhao et al. (2018), and empirical evaluation thereof  Wang et al. (2021); Zhao et al. (2018), and empirical evaluation thereof Wang et al. (2023a, b). In this section, we provide a representative sample of the work in this area, directing the reader’s attention to the surveys by  Wang et al. (2023a, b). In this section, we provide a representative sample of the work in this area, directing the reader’s attention to the surveys by Zhu et al. (2021); Ma et al. (2022); Lu et al. (2024) for a more comprehensive overview. Zhu et al. (2021); Ma et al. (2022); Lu et al. (2024) for a more comprehensive overview.

Multiple authors have proposed, implemented, and tested novel algorithms for performing \glsabb:fl on the edge with non-\glsabb:iid data. Different surveys of the literature Zhu et al. (2021); Ma et al. (2022); Lu et al. (2024) introduced different categorizations of these methods. Two recurring categories are data-based and algorithm-based methods, corresponding roughly to preprocessing and in-processing methods in our taxonomy. Both categories contain a variety of methods, a subset of which we will discuss in this section. Zhu et al. (2021); Ma et al. (2022); Lu et al. (2024) introduced different categorizations of these methods. Two recurring categories are data-based and algorithm-based methods, corresponding roughly to preprocessing and in-processing methods in our taxonomy. Both categories contain a variety of methods, a subset of which we will discuss in this section.

The motivating intuition behind data-based methods is that modifying the local datasets to make them more homogeneous will lead to better performance when training a global model. Three main approaches to achieving this have been proposed: data selection, data augmentation, and data selection Zhu et al. (2021); Ma et al. (2022). Zhu et al. (2021); Ma et al. (2022).

Algorithm-based methods are in-processing methods that amend the training algorithm
to make it more robust to non-\glsabb:iid data.
Due to the complex and multi-component nature of the \glsabb:fl training process,
these methods are more varied and technically sophisticated than data-based methods.

Jiang et al. (2023) propose a model agnostic meta-learning approach  Jiang et al. (2023) propose a model agnostic meta-learning approach Finn et al. (2017) to simultaneously improve personalization and convergence speed. Another work by Finn et al. (2017) to simultaneously improve personalization and convergence speed. In a different vein, Zhang et al. (2021) propose a meta-algorithm based on the primal-dual algorithm. Their method produces strong convergence guarantees even with non- Zhang et al. (2021) propose a meta-algorithm based on the primal-dual algorithm. Their method produces strong convergence guarantees even with non-\glsabb:iid data and non-convex objectives. Personalization can be cast as a multitask learning problem Zhu et al. (2021). Works that have addressed Zhu et al. (2021). The majority of literature on theoretical \glsabb:fl with non-\glsabb:iid data focuses on convergence. For example, Li et al. (2020) prove convergence theorems and rates for Li et al. (2020) prove convergence theorems and rates for \glsabb:fedavg with non-\glsabb:iid data under certain conditions on the smoothness and convexity of the loss function, and the boundedness of the gradients. Lee (2023) also provide convergence guarantees for federated regression assuming similar rather than identical local distributions. Lee (2023) also provide convergence guarantees for federated regression assuming similar rather than identical local distributions.

Label noise, or labeling error, is a term used to qualify any situation where the label present in a dataset is different from the target Frenay and Verleysen (2014). This can be due to human error, communication and storage defects  Frenay and Verleysen (2014). This can be due to human error, communication and storage defects Baccour et al. (2022) (very common on the edge), and deliberate mislabeling  Baccour et al. (2022) (very common on the edge), and deliberate mislabeling Frenay and Verleysen (2014); Song et al. (2023). It is not difficult to see how the presence of noise can be problematic, particularly for highly expressive models such as Frenay and Verleysen (2014); Song et al. (2023). It is not difficult to see how the presence of noise can be problematic, particularly for highly expressive models such as \glsplabb:dnn, which are susceptible to overfitting.

Fairness is a critical ethical consideration in the design of any decision-making process (automated or otherwise) that affects humans. In the context of edge \glsabb:fl, we can distinguish between two types of fairness Vucinich and Zhu (2023), broadly corresponding to the traditional notions of Vucinich and Zhu (2023), broadly corresponding to the traditional notions of outcome fairness and process fairness Grgić-Hlača et al. (2018) from the literature on algorithmic fairness. We refer to them as social fairness and cooperative fairness, respectively. The latter is of particular interest in the context of Grgić-Hlača et al. (2018) from the literature on algorithmic fairness. We refer to them as social fairness and cooperative fairness, respectively. The latter is of particular interest in the context of \glsabb:fl, given its procedural divergence from traditional \glsabb:ml. While social fairness is concerned with the model making fair predictions, cooperative fairness is concerned with the training process producing a fair model.

Privacy is one of the main selling points of \glsabb:fl. By abolishing the need to share data, conventional wisdom says, \glsabb:fl guarantees data privacy. However, this guarantee rings hollow in the face of numerous privacy attacks Carlini et al. (2021); Pasquini et al. (2022); Li et al. (2023); Balle et al. (2022). While it is true that Carlini et al. (2021); Pasquini et al. (2022); Li et al. (2023); Balle et al. (2022). While it is true that \glsabb:fl blocks traditional avenues of data theft that rely on compromising a central server or intercepting data in transit, it leaves open other attack angles that rely on what is shared: model updates, the final model parameters, or, failing that, the model’s predictions Shokri et al. (2017); Carlini et al. (2021). This state of affairs jeopardizes the privacy of individuals whose data is used in edge Shokri et al. (2017); Carlini et al. (2021). This state of affairs jeopardizes the privacy of individuals whose data is used in edge \glsabb:fl systems, and poses significant ethical and legal risks to the organizations that deploy them Truong et al. (2021). In this section, we explore privacy threats to edge Truong et al. (2021). In this section, we explore privacy threats to edge \glsabb:fl, proposed defenses, and their limitations.

The thesis that \glsabb:fl guarantees privacy is based on
the simplistic assumption that data is private unless explicitly shared,
a consequence of which is that sharing a model trained on data does not compromise its privacy.
This assumption is patently false, as the model’s parameters contain —at the very least—
information on the data distribution, otherwise the model would not be useful.
The relevant question is therefore not whether the model contains private information,
but rather


(a) how much information it contains,

(b) and how much of that information can be extracted.

Even this view, however, underestimates models’ information leakage. While classical \glsabb:ml wisdom, embodied by the bias-variance trade-off, dictates that \glsplabb:nn must have as many parameters as necessary to fit training data, but no more to avoid overfitting, recent research has shown that they can be largely overparameterized, yet have excellent generalization performance. In fact, a neural network with zero empirical risk (i.e., one that interpolates training data) can have lower risk than one that slightly underfits the data Belkin et al. (2019); Belkin (2021). Due to this phenomenon, usually referred to as Belkin et al. (2019); Belkin (2021). Due to this phenomenon, usually referred to as double descent, large modern \glsplabb:dnn tend to operate in the so-called interpolation regime. That is to say, not only do \glsplabb:nn contain information about the training data, in many cases, they contain all the information about it. This implies a worst-case answer to question (a), leaving question (b) as the only hope for defending the privacy of \glsabb:fl. Unfortunately, the answer to this question is also pessimistic. As we demonstrate in \Crefsub:privacy:attacks, it is possible to extract a significant amount of information about the training data from surprisingly little information about the model Jere et al. (2021); Rodríguez-Barroso et al. (2023). Vanilla Jere et al. (2021); Rodríguez-Barroso et al. (2023). Vanilla \glsabb:fl is in this sense no more private than centralized \glsabb:ml. As such, modifications to \glsabb:fl are necessary to ensure privacy.

Perturbation-based privacy-preserving edge \glsabb:fl suffers from an inherent trade-off between privacy and accuracy Kim et al. (2021). Encryption-based defenses, on the other hand, appear to have no such trade-off because they preserve Kim et al. (2021). Encryption-based defenses, on the other hand, appear to have no such trade-off because they preserve 100 % percent 100 100\% 100 % of the transmitted information. From this observation, two conclusions can be drawn. Either 100 % percent 100 100\% 100 % 100 % 100 100% % percent 100 percent 100 percent percent100 100100\% 100\%100 % 100 % of the transmitted information. From this observation, two conclusions can be drawn. Either (1) encryption-based defenses are inherently superior to perturbation-based defenses, or (2) encryption-based defenses are not as effective as they appear.

In the case of \glsabb:he, the latter conclusion is more likely. As a matter of fact, the model learned by the server under \glsabb:he is theoretically identical to the one learned under vanilla \glsabb:fl. The only difference is that individual updates are not shared. This implies that all the black-box attacks enumerated in \Crefsub:privacy:attacks, as well as the attacks on the final model parameters, are still possible against an edge \glsabb:fl system secured with \glsabb:he. As for \glsabb:smc, successful attacks against secure aggregation have been demonstrated in the literature Pasquini et al. (2022), supporting the second conclusion in this case as well. This pessimistic analysis is made rigorous by  Pasquini et al. (2022), supporting the second conclusion in this case as well. This pessimistic analysis is made rigorous by El-Mhamdi et al. (2023), where the authors prove the existence of a trade-off between model accuracy and differential privacy, which becomes less favorable as the heterogeneity of the data increases. As a result, the El-Mhamdi et al. (2023), where the authors prove the existence of a trade-off between model accuracy and differential privacy, which becomes less favorable as the heterogeneity of the data increases. As a result, the only way to ensure \glsabb:dp, is to sacrifice model accuracy.

As established in \Crefsec:data_quality, rather than being an intrinsic property of the data, \glsabb:dq is strongly dependent on extrinsic and contextual factors. Having introduced two such factors, namely fairness and privacy in \Crefsec:fairness,sec:privacy, we now turn our attention to a third one: trustworthiness. Instead of being a property of the data, trustworthiness is a property of the data source, it allows for different treatments of identical data points depending on their provenance. Despite the extrinsic nature of trustworthiness, it is a ubiquitous dimension in the \glsabb:dq literature Restuccia et al. (2017); Hassenstein and Vanella (2022); Wang and Strong (1996); Sidi et al. (2012). It is even more salient for Restuccia et al. (2017); Hassenstein and Vanella (2022); Wang and Strong (1996); Sidi et al. (2012). It is even more salient for \glsabb:fl on the edge, where the data is private, and the clients are potentially anonymous. This section is dedicated to the study of untrusted clients in \glsabb:fl (also known as Byzantine clients for reasons that will become clear), and the defenses that can be deployed against them.

Despite the plethora of defense strategies we have enumerated (which represent a vanishingly small fraction of the literature), the problem of ensuring Byzantine fault tolerance on the edge is far from solved. El-Mhamdi et al. (2023) have shown that securing El-Mhamdi et al. (2023) have shown that securing \glsabb:fl against poisoning attacks is impossible if the datasets of honest clients are heterogeneous. They manage this by leveraging an equivalence result between robust mean estimation and robust \glsabb:fl El-Mhamdi et al. (2021), which they combine with a proof of impossibility for robust mean estimation to conclude. Given existing results on the possibility of Byzantine-robust \glsabb:fl with homogeneous honest clients Karimireddy et al. (2021); El-Mhamdi et al. (2021), Karimireddy et al. (2021); El-Mhamdi et al. (2021), El-Mhamdi et al. (2023) conclude that heterogeneity is the key obstacle. El-Mhamdi et al. (2023) conclude that heterogeneity is the key obstacle.

In this survey, we discussed the problems data can pose for \glsabb:ml on the edge.
Starting with a general formulation of the learning problem in terms of \glsabb:erm
and \glsabb:ferm, we introduced a characterization of data quality in terms of
six dimensions justified by the statistical properties
of the learning problem and social/ethical considerations.
For each of these dimensions, we discussed, to the extent literature permits,
the challenges they pose, the methods to address them, and the limitations of these methods.
In doing this, we remained focused on the specific challenges
that arise in the context of \glsabb:fl on the edge
and the solutions that are tailored to this context.
We conclude by discussing some open problems and potential avenues for future exploration.

Multiple \glsabb:dq-related questions remain unanswered,
even more so in the context of \glsabb:fl.
These include:

Other data quality considerations.
The list of dimensions discussed in this survey is not exhaustive.
This is particularly true of extrinsic dimensions
but is also true of intrinsic dimensions,
which can be subdivided into more specific categories.
Examples of subtleties that have not been discussed include:

Shortcuts Wu et al. (2023); Geirhos et al. (2020), a special form of bias in the conditional distribution. Wu et al. (2023); Geirhos et al. (2020), a special form of bias in the conditional distribution.

Temporal and spatial dependencies Wang et al. (2023); Li and Wang (2022), which often lead to dependent and attribute skewed data. Wang et al. (2023); Li and Wang (2022), which often lead to dependent and attribute skewed data.

Missing data Guastella et al. (2021); You et al. (2020), which can reduce the effective sample size and introduce bias. Guastella et al. (2021); You et al. (2020), which can reduce the effective sample size and introduce bias.

The interplay between \glsabb:dq dimensions. The dimensions discussed in this survey are not orthogonal. Many of them are correlated, while others are in conflict, and it is not always clear which is the case. For example, some works suggest that differential privacy and social fairness are equivalent Dwork et al. (2012), while others find a trade-off between them  Dwork et al. (2012), while others find a trade-off between them Rafi et al. (2024). Other dimensions that can be related include: cooperative fairness, noise resilience, and Byzantine fault tolerance. Rafi et al. (2024). Other dimensions that can be related include: cooperative fairness, noise resilience, and Byzantine fault tolerance.

Understanding the effect of data quality on the learning process. While \glsabb:dq’s influence on the learning process is both intuitive and empirically validated, it is not yet well understood. Despite attempts to rigorously study it both theoretically Izzo et al. (2023) and experimentally  Izzo et al. (2023) and experimentally Qi et al. (2021), a unified theory of data quality does not yet exist for Qi et al. (2021), a unified theory of data quality does not yet exist for \glsabb:ml, let alone for \glsabb:fl. Characterizing the relationship between data and different aspects of the learning process such as the loss landscape, convergence and convergence rate, quality of the local minima, and generalization error, as well as the changes this relationship undergoes in the distributed setting, is an important, fertile, and largely underexplored area of research. If pursued, this line of research has the potential to facilitate the establishment of universally accepted definitions of data quality, and motivate sound practices for its assessment and improvement.

abb:dq-robust learning algorithms. Most existing methods for addressing \glsabb:dq issues rely on in-processing. This trend is likely to continue in the future, as learning algorithms are the most complex, sophisticated, and flexible components of the \glsabb:ml pipeline. While researchers exert very little control over the data collection process, the learning algorithm is completely under their control. Focusing on this component is also motivated by our observation of biological learning, which can extract useful models from noisy, biased, dependent, and untrusted data. Problems that lie in this space include \glsabb:ood, where methods like \glsabb:dro and \glsabb:irm have already been proposed  Zhou et al. (2022), algorithmic robustness, and algorithmic stability. Zhou et al. (2022), algorithmic robustness, and algorithmic stability.
